Name: N-PROPYL ACETATE
Description: Propyl acetate is an acetate ester obtained by the formal condensation of acetic acid with propanol. It has a role as a fragrance and a plant metabolite. It is functionally related to a propan-1-ol.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Hansch C et al; Exploring QSAR. Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. ACS Prof Ref Book. Heller SR, consult. ed., Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc p. 14 (1995) (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-72 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 3 was calculated in fish for n-propyl acetate(SRC), using a log Kow of 1.24(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Price KS et al; J Water Poll Control Fed 46: 63-77 (1974) (2) Dorigan J et al; Preliminary scoring of selected organic air pollutants. Appendix IV - Chemistry, Production and Toxicity of Chemicals O through Z. USEPA-450/3-77-008e. Research Triangle Park, NC USEPA pp 331 (1976) (3) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of Oct 19, 2011: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: n-Propyl acetate gave a 5-day theoretical BOD of 62% using a settled domestic wastewater seed, the 10-day theoretical BOD was 80%(1). When the same inoculum was added to sea water, the percent theoretical BOD was 50% (5-day) and 70% (10-day)(1). n-Propyl acetate had a theoretical BOD of 72% after 20 days at 20 °C(2). n-Propyl acetate, present at 100 mg/L, reached 81.0% of its theoretical BOD in 2 weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test(3).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Marion CV, Malaney GW; J Water Poll Control Fed 35: 1269-84 (1963)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: PURE CULTURE: Pure cultures of Alcaligenes faecalis, isolated from activated sludge, were found to oxidize n-propyl acetate after a short lag period(1).

logP.References: Hansch, C., Leo, A., D. Hoekman. Exploring QSAR - Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. Washington, DC: American Chemical Society., 1995., p. 14

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists, Inc. Documentation of the Threshold Limit Values and Biological Exposure Indices. 6th ed. Volumes I, II, III. Cincinnati, OH: ACGIH, 1991., p. 1300
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ ... THE LIMITING /SRP: CNS DEPRESSANT/ CONCN FOR 5-HR EXPOSURE WAS 9,000 PPM FOR CATS & 6,000 PPM FOR MICE. ... /SRP: CNS DEPRESSANT/ ACTION, RELATIVE TO THAT OF ETHYL ACETATE, WAS STATED TO BE 1.3. EXPOSURES AT 2600 PPM CAUSED SALIVATION AND EYE IRRITATION IN CATS. ... A 4-HR EXPOSURE AT 8,000 PPM WAS FATAL TO FOUR OF SIX RATS.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. V6 562
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Cats exposed to a concn of 5300 ppm propyl acetate for 6 hr/day resulted in moderate irritation, salivation. Exposures to 7400 ppm propyl acetate for 5.5 hrs resulted in staggering within 30-45 min, deep /SRP: CNS depression/ 4.5-5.5 hr, 25% died after 5.5 hr. Exposures to 24000 ppm propyl acetate for 0.5 hr resulted in /SRP: CNS depression/ within 13-18 min and 25% died 4-days post exposure. /From table/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Browning, E. Toxicity and Metabolism of Industrial Solvents. New York: American Elsevier, 1965., p. 534
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ ... CAT EXPOSED TO LETHAL CONCN SHOWED TRACHEITIS, BRONCHITIS AND FATTY CHANGES IN LIVER.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 19, 2011: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc of n-propyl acetate can be estimated to be 10(SRC). According to a classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that n-propyl acetate is expected to have very high mobility in soil.
